title: Syrian army joins forces with Kurds as outcry against Turkey intensifies
text:
A wounded child receives treatment following Turkey’s moves against Kurdish fighters in Syria (Picture: EPA)

Kurdish fighters say they have joined forces with Syrian troops in an effort to repel Turkey’s military offensive into the war-torn Middle Eastern country.

The move marks an abrupt shift in Kurdish fighters’ allegiances, after they fought alongside American forces against Islamic State (IS).

But with Turkish troops crossing the northern border early last week, state media says Syrian troops have joined the fighting as the international outcry intensified.

Turkey’s offensive began after US President Donald Trump unexpectedly said he would pull American troops out of the region. That sparked fears of a resurgent IS, with around 800 Islamist fighters escaping Kurdish-run prisons as fighting intensified.

Syria’s Kurds had been a key ally in the fight against IS and considered Mr Trump’s move a betrayal.

A wounded civilian injured in an alleged Turkish airstrike receives medical treatment at a hospital in Tal Tamr, northeastern Syria (Picture: EPA)

Medics attend to the wounded (Picture: EPA)

Turkey says it is aiming to neutralize the Kurdish YPG militia, which it views as a terrorist group due to ties with a Kurdish insurgency in Turkey.

This weekend it heavily bombarded areas under the control of Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) – linked to the YPD.

But there has been widespread outrage over Turkey’s conduct, which has been blamed for a number of civilian deaths.

The Chernobyl residents who refused to leave against all government and safety advice

World leaders hit out at Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdogan, while the EU said it would stop arms sales to the country.

Spanish Foreign Minister Josep Borrel said the EU was calling on Turkey ‘to stop immediately these military actions.’

Mr Erdogan said both Germany’s Angela Merkel and Britain’s Boris Johnson did not ‘know the truths’ about Turkey’s operation and were under ‘serious disinformation pressure’ after speaking to them.

But despite the criticism from NATO allies, Turkey showed little sign of backtracking.

Its defence minister Hulusi Akar accused Syrian Kurdish fighters of ‘emptying a prison’ in northeast Syria holding Islamic State group militants before Turkish troops arrived in the area.

Turkey says it is determined to fight the IS group in addition to the Syrian Kurdish forces that it considers a threat.

Meanwhile, President Trump claimed on Twitter that Kurdish-led forces might be intentionally releasing IS militants to lure the US back into the fighting.
